docs.snippet: The agreement would let businesses like Google and Facebook continue to move personal data across the Atlantic, but European privacy officials may balk.

headline.print_headline: Deal Struck to Balance U.S.-Europe Data Fears
headline.main: U.S. and Europe in ‘Safe Harbor’ Data Deal, but Legal Fight May Await

docs.abstract: European Union officials reach agreement with United States that will allow companies to continue moving customers' digital data back and forth between continents; deal is result of months of often tense negotiations that pitted individuals' privacy concerns against those of national security.

docs.snippet: Apple’s legal battle with the government tests the limits of law enforcement agencies’ access to personal data.

headline.print_headline: Tech Rivals Lining Up  to Support  Apple’s Case
headline.main: Apple Is Rolling Up Backers in iPhone Privacy Fight Against F.B.I.

docs.abstract: Google, Amazon, Facebook, Microsoft and others file court briefs in support of Apple's resistance to Federal Bureau of Investigation's demand to break into iPhone used by San Bernardino gunman; moves come as test of limits of government access to personal data.

docs.snippet: A summary of the latest developments in the battle between Apple and the F.B.I. over unlocking an iPhone used by one of the attackers in the mass shooting in San Bernardino, Calif.

headline.main: A Brief Explanation of Apple’s Showdown With the U.S. Government

docs.snippet: Lara Casalotti’s search for a stem cell donor that matches her Italian, Thai and Chinese ancestry has gone viral, attracting international attention and scores of new potential donors.

headline.main: #Match4Lara: Mixed-Race Marrow Search That’s Going Viral

docs.abstract: Lara Casalotti’s search for a stem cell donor that matches her Italian, Thai and Chinese ancestry has gone viral, attracting international attention and scores of new potential donors.

docs.snippet: A complicated set of factors influences the reactions of technology companies to government demands to unlock a path to customer data.

headline.print_headline: Apple’s Stance Draws Muted Response From Its Tech Peers
headline.main: Apple Letter on iPhone Security Draws Muted Tech Industry Response

docs.abstract: Range of mostly muted responses by Apple's peers to company's resistance to federal court order to unlock iPhone used by San Bernardino gunman underscores complex factors affecting tech firms' reactions to government demands for customer data; some companies worry over becoming political  targets of presidential contenders.

docs.snippet: The Apple-F.B.I. fray, in a terrorism case no less, is reverberating throughout the digital world, with some East Coast-West Coast divergences.

headline.main: Farhad and Mike Hash Out the Week’s Big Topic: Apple

docs.abstract: Photos from The New York Times and photographers from around the world.

docs.snippet: As the stock market continues its 2016 slide, technology stocks are falling even further, victims partly of their own success.

headline.print_headline: Tech Stocks Drop Faster  and Further Than Average
headline.main: Tech Stocks Have Fallen Faster and Further Than Broader Market

docs.abstract: Technology stocks are falling even further than wider stock market, victims of their previous success as well as fears about global economic health and possible reduction in business spending.

docs.snippet: Margrethe Vestager’s warning shot comes ahead of a Jan. 31 deadline for Europe and the United States to reach a new data-sharing agreement.

headline.print_headline: Antitrust Chief Takes Swipe in Privacy Issue
headline.main: European Antitrust Chief Takes Swipe at Privacy Issue

docs.abstract: European Union antitrust chief Margrethe Vestager fires warning shot at companies like Google and Facebook, saying that their widespread collection of user data might run afoul of Continent's competition rules; Vestager's voice joins chorus of other European officials who are growing increasingly assertive about data protection and digital privacy.
